"sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-06/israeli-strike-on-nuseirat-school-kills-dozens-of-palestinians/103947744", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at Gaza school that military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "An Israeli strike at a UN school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza has killed more than 30 people, according to local health officials.\n\nThis total included 23 women and children.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from within the Nuseirat school.\n\nThe strike came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there.\n\nIt is the latest instance of troops sweeping back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously attacked.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the pre-dawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA.\n\nThe school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital.\n\nAnother strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat.\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, described chaotic scenes outside the facility.\n\nHe said vehicles arrived one after the other, as distressed people rushed wounded people into the emergency department.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital, which was largely dark as staff try to conserve limited fuel for electricity.\n\nMr Al-Kareem said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" within the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops.\n\nThe military did not immediately offer evidence.\n\nIt released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nIsraeli military spokesperson Lt Col Peter Lerner said 20-30 fighters were located in the school and many had been killed.\n\nHe said he was unaware of civilian casualties from the strike.\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas's October 7 terrorist attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage.\n\nIsrael's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe US has thrown its weight behind a phased ceasefire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week.\n\nBut Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting ceasefire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe Israeli military said on Wednesday local time that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza.\n\nIt said the operation began with air strikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 injured people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of strikes.\n\nThe international charity said on Wednesday in a post on social media platform X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital was struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other {"uri": "8164169428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:22:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:22:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:21:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-kills-more-than-30-people-military-claims-it-was-being/article_cee42a87-8a84-5e5c-aff1-07839f5d6160.html", "title": "Israeli strike on Gaza school kills more than 30 people. Military claims it was being used by Hamas", "body": "Palestinians mourn their relatives killed in an Israeli bombardment of UNRWA school at Nusseirat refugee camp, in front of the morgue of al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip, early Thursday, June 6, 2024.\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nThe strike came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. It's the latest instance of troops sweeping back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, described chaotic scenes outside the facility. He said vehicles arrived one after the other, as distressed people rushed wounded people into the emergency department. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital, which was largely dark as staff try to conserve limited fuel for electricity. Al-Kareem said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" within the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops, though it did not immediately offer evidence. It released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\n\nGaza's health system has nearly collapsed through almost eight months of war. The hospital, which was treating some 700 wounded and sick people before the latest strikes, said Wednesday that one of its two electrical generators had stopped working, threatening its ability to keep operating ventilators and incubators for premature babies.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.\n\nMagdy reported from Cairo.\n\nFollow AP's coverage at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@eagletribune.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "samy_magdy@eagletribune.com", "name": "Samy Magdy", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "wafaa_shurafa@eagletribune.com", "name": "Wafaa Shurafa", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinian_refugees", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Palestinian refugees"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNRWA", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "UNRWA"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinians", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Palestinians"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deir_al-Balah", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Deir al-Balah"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "2024-06-380356368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:35:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:35:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:21:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/news/world/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-that-military-says-was-being-used-by-hamas-kills-30/article_fe495317-9aed-50e9-9830-84fe7bcc79b8.html", "title": "Israeli strike on Gaza school that military says was being used by Hamas kills 30 people", "body": "Palestinian health officials say an Israeli strike on a school in central Gaza killed at least 30 people overnight\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike on a school in central Gaza that the military said was being used as a \"Hamas compound\" killed at least 30 people, according to local health officials.\n\nThe overnight strike, which came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza and and international medical group reported soaring casualties from strikes in the area.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run media had earlier reported a higher toll from the strike on the school.\n\nThe Israeli military said Thursday its fighter jets struck the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known by the acronym UNRWA. The Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations.\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has displaced most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians.\n\n\"Before the strike, a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike, including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information,\" the Israeli military said.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating back to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nThe latest war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nThe military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah last month in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.", "source": {"uri": "santamariatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Santa Maria {"uri": "8164186902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:34:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:34:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:34:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.glasgowtimes.co.uk/news/national/24369452.israeli-strike-kills-30-people-gaza-school-being-used-hamas/", "title": "Israeli strike kills more than 30 people at Gaza school 'being used by Hamas'", "body": "An Israeli strike on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza has killed more than 30 people including 23 women and children, according to health officials.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from the school in Nuseirat.\n\nThe strike on Thursday came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing militants it says have regrouped there.\n\nIt is the latest instance of troops sweeping back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the pre-dawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known as UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital.\n\nAnother strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nOnline footage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital, which was largely dark as staff try to conserve limited fuel for electricity.\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among the bodies, adding: \"The situation is tragic.\"\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" in the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops.\n\nIt released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information\".\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas's October 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage.\n\nIsrael's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe US has thrown its weight behind a phased ceasefire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week, but Israel says it will not end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting ceasefire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said on Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with air strikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were taken to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said on Wednesday {"uri": "2024-06-380497523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:25:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:25:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:00:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-kills-more-than-30-people-military-claims-it-was-being/article_57cf7efb-bacc-5a7c-9e6b-283694c64c7d.html", "title": "Israeli strike on Gaza school kills more than 30 people. Military claims it was being used by Hamas", "body": "DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nThe strike came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. It's the latest instance of troops sweeping back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, described chaotic scenes outside the facility. He said vehicles arrived one after the other, as distressed people rushed wounded people into the emergency department. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital, which was largely dark as staff try to conserve limited fuel for electricity. Al-Kareem said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" within the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops, though it did not immediately offer evidence. It released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\n\nGaza's health system has nearly collapsed through almost eight months of war. The hospital, which was treating some 700 wounded and sick people before the latest strikes, said Wednesday that one of its two electrical generators had stopped working, threatening its ability to keep operating ventilators and incubators for premature babies.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.\n\nMagdy reported from Cairo.\n\nFollow AP's coverage at {"uri": "8163981564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:56:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:56:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:54:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-that-military-says-was-being-used-by-hamas-kills-30/article_cee42a87-8a84-5e5c-aff1-07839f5d6160.html", "title": "Israeli strike on Gaza school that military says was being used by Hamas kills 30 people", "body": "Palestinians mourn their relatives killed in an Israeli bombardment of UNRWA school at Nusseirat refugee camp, in front of the morgue of al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip, early Thursday, June 6, 2024.\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military said was being used as a \"Hamas compound\" killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza and an international medical group reported soaring casualties. The latest operations appear to mark a widening of Israel's nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run media had earlier reported a higher toll from the strike on the school.\n\nThe Israeli military said its fighter jets struck the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known by the acronym UNRWA. The Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations.\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has displaced most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians.\n\n\"Before the strike, a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike, including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information,\" the Israeli military said.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating back to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nThe latest war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\n\nGaza's health system has nearly collapsed through almost eight months of war. The hospital, which was treating some 700 wounded and sick people before the latest strikes, said Wednesday that one of its two electrical generators had stopped working, threatening its ability to keep operating ventilators and incubators for premature babies.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah last month in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.\n\nMagdy reported from Cairo.\n\nFollow AP's coverage at {"uri": "8164310147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:55:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:55:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:53:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/israeli-strike-kills-at-least-33-people-at-gaza-school-the-military-claims-was-being/article_cee42a87-8a84-5e5c-aff1-07839f5d6160.html", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "Palestinians mourn relatives killed in an Israeli strike on Israeli strike on a U.N.-run school in the Nusseirat refugee camp, outside a hospital in Deir al Balah, Gaza Strip, Thursday, June 6, 2024.\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensives in the Gaza Strip. A day earlier, the military announced a a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital -- there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" within the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops, though it didn't immediately offer evidence. It released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas militants. An inferno that followed ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families , killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal. On Wednesday, National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, a leading hard-liner, spoke at an annual march through Jerusalem's Old City, saying, \"We are delivering a message from here to Hamas: Jerusalem is ours. Damascus Gate is ours\" -- referring to a main gate into the Arab-majority section of the city -- \"And with God's help total victory is ours.\"\n\nThe annual march commemorates \"Jerusalem Day,\" which marks Israel's capture of east Jerusalem, including the Old City and its holy sites sacred to Jews, Christians and Muslims, in the 1967 Middle East war.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nSamy Magdy reported from Cairo.\n\nFollow AP's coverage at {"uri": "8164761073", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:24:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:24:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:23:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.vindy.com/news/latest-news/2024/06/israeli-strike-kills-at-least-33-people-at-a-gaza-school-the-military-claims-was-being-used-by-hamas/", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at a Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "Palestinians look at the aftermath of the Israeli strike on a U.N.-run school that killed dozens of people in the Nusseirat refugee camp in the Gaza Strip, Thursday, June 6, 2024. An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school. (AP Photo/Jehad Alshrafi)\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike earlier today on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensive. A day earlier, the military announced a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into parts of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli operations and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital.\n\nVideos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital -- there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nPhilippe Lazzarini, the commissioner-general of UNRWA, said in a post on X that 6,000 people were sheltering in the school when it was hit without prior warning. He said UNRWA was unable to verify claims that armed groups were inside.\n\nAn Israeli military spokesman, Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, said that the army wasn't aware of any civilian casualties in the strike. He said that intelligence indicated that militants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on Oct. 7 and that at least 20 militants there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers. The military gave no evidence for its claims and released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nThe military said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas militants. An inferno ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families , killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.", "source": {"uri": "vindy.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Vindicator"}, {"uri": "2024-06-380371016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:58:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:58:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T03:45:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/06/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-that-military-says-was-being-used-by-hamas-kills-30-people/", "title": "Israeli strike on Gaza school that military says was being used by Hamas kills 30 people", "body": "DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military said was being used as a \"Hamas compound\" killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza and an international medical group reported soaring casualties. The latest operations appear to mark a widening of Israel's nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run media had earlier reported a higher toll from the strike on the school.\n\nThe Israeli military said its fighter jets struck the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known by the acronym UNRWA. The Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations.\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has displaced most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians.\n\n\"Before the strike, a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike, including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information,\" the Israeli military said.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating back to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nThe latest war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\n\nGaza's health system has nearly collapsed through almost eight months of war. The hospital, which was treating some 700 wounded and sick people before the latest strikes, said Wednesday that one of its two electrical generators had stopped working, threatening its ability to keep operating ventilators and incubators for premature babies.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah last month in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, {"uri": "8164187493", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:35:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:35:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:34:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/06/06/israeli-strike-kills-more-than-30-people-at-gaza-school-being-used-by-hamas/", "title": "Israeli strike kills more than 30 people at Gaza school 'being used by Hamas'", "body": "An Israeli strike on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza has killed more than 30 people including 23 women and children, according to health officials.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from the school in Nuseirat.\n\nThe strike on Thursday came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing militants it says have regrouped there.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the pre-dawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known as UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital.\n\nAnother strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nOnline footage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital, which was largely dark as staff try to conserve limited fuel for electricity.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" in the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops.\n\nIt released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information\".\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas's October 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe US has thrown its weight behind a phased ceasefire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week, but Israel says it will not end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting ceasefire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said on Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with air strikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were taken to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said on Wednesday that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital was struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries\".", "source": {"uri": "8164395545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:47:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:47:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:45:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/israeli-strike-kills-at-least-33-people-at-a-gaza-school-the-military-claims-was/article_cee42a87-8a84-5e5c-aff1-07839f5d6160.html", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at a Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "Palestinians mourn relatives killed in an Israeli strike on Israeli strike on a U.N.-run school in the Nusseirat refugee camp, outside a hospital in Deir al Balah, Gaza Strip, Thursday, June 6, 2024.\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensives in the Gaza Strip. A day earlier, the military announced a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital -- there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nAn Israeli military spokesman, Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, said that the army wasn't aware of any civilian casualties in the strike. He said that intelligence indicated that militants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on Oct. 7 and that at least 20 militants there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers. The military gave no evidence for its claims and released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nThe miltiary said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas militants. An inferno that followed ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families , killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal. On Wednesday, National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, a leading hard-liner, spoke at an annual march through Jerusalem's Old City, saying, \"We are delivering a message from here to Hamas: Jerusalem is ours. Damascus Gate is ours\" -- referring to a main gate into the Arab-majority section of the city -- \"And with God's help total victory is ours.\"\n\nThe annual march commemorates \"Jerusalem Day,\" which marks Israel's capture of east Jerusalem, including the Old City and its holy sites sacred to Jews, Christians and Muslims, in the 1967 Middle East war.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nSamy Magdy reported from Cairo.\n\nFollow AP's coverage at {"uri": "8163960917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:33:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:33:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:32:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/05/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-that-military-says-was-being-used-by-hamas-kills-30-people/", "title": "Israeli strike on Gaza school that military says was being used by Hamas kills 30 people - Medicine Hat News", "body": "Palestinians check the bodies of their relatives killed in an Israeli bombardment of UNRWA school at Nusseirat refugee camp, in front of the morgue of al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip, early Thursday, June 6, 2024. (AP Photo/Abdel Kareem Hana)DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) - An Israeli strike on a school in central Gaza that the military said was being used as a \"Hamas compound\" killed at least 30 people, according to local health officials. The overnight strike, which came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza and and international medical group reported soaring casualties from strikes in the area. The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run media had earlier reported a higher toll from the strike on the school. The Israeli military said Thursday its fighter jets struck the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known by the acronym UNRWA. The Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations. UNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has displaced most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians. \"Before the strike, a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike, including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information,\"\u009d the Israeli military said. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating back to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state. The latest war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures. The military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\"\u009d in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\"\u009d in both areas. Doctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes. The international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\u009d Israel has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins. The military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza. Troops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles. Israel sent troops into Rafah last month in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine {"uri": "2024-06-380439355", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:23:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:23:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:22:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://gulftoday.ae/news/2024/06/06/israeli-airstrike-on-gaza-school-kills-30", "title": "Israeli airstrike on Gaza school kills 30", "body": "Palestinians mourn their relatives killed in an Israeli bombardment of UNRWA school at Nusseirat refugee camp, in front of the morgue of al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip, early on Thursday. AP\n\nAn Israeli strike early on Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military claimed was being used as a Hamas compound killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza in an apparent widening of its nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack. An international medical charity had reported soaring casualties even before Thursday's strike.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run TV had earlier reported a higher toll.\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, described chaotic scenes outside the facility. He said vehicles arrived one after the other, as distressed people rushed wounded people into the emergency department. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards.\n\nLater, he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies wrapped in white shrouds in the hospital courtyard. He said one woman kept asking medical workers to open them up to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nThe Israeli military said its fighter jets struck the school that it claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used as cover for their operations.\n\nSmoke rises over the Gaza Strip, following an Israeli airstrike near the Israel-Gaza border on Wednesday. Reuters\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has displaced most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians.\n\n\"Before the strike, a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike, including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information,\" the Israeli military said.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating back to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nIsrael says it takes measures to avoid harming civilians and blames their deaths of Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas. The military rarely comments on individual strikes, which often kill women and children.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nPalestinians bring people killed in the Israeli bombardment into a hospital in Deir al Ballah, Gaza, on Wednesday. The hospital, which was treating some 700 wounded and sick people before the latest strikes, said Wednesday that one of its two electrical generators had stopped working, threatening its ability to keep operating ventilators and incubators for premature babies.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction.
