{"uri": "8164025367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:32:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:32:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:32:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/05/an-israeli-strike-on-a-gaza-school-that-the-military-claims-was-being-used-by-hamas-kills-30-people/", "title": "An Israeli strike on a Gaza school that the military claims was being used by Hamas kills 30 people - Medicine Hat News", "body": "Palestinians check the bodies of their relatives killed in an Israeli bombardment of UNRWA school at Nusseirat refugee camp, in front of the morgue of al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip, early Thursday, June 6, 2024. (AP Photo/Abdel Kareem Hana)DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) - An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military claimed was being used as a Hamas compound killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials. The strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza in an apparent widening of its nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack. An international medical charity had reported soaring casualties even before Thursday's strike. The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees - known by the acronym UNRWA - and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run TV had earlier reported a higher toll. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, described chaotic scenes outside the facility. He said vehicles arrived one after the other, as distressed people rushed wounded people into the emergency department. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Later, he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies wrapped in white shrouds in the hospital courtyard. He said one woman kept asking medical workers to open them up to see if her son was inside. \"The situation is tragic,\" he said. The Israeli military said its fighter jets struck the school that it claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used as cover for their operations. UNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has displaced most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians. \"Before the strike, a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike, including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information,\"\u009d the Israeli military said. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating back to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state. The latest war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures. Israel says it takes measures to avoid harming civilians and blames their deaths of Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas. The military rarely comments on individual strikes, which often kill women and children. The United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces. The military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\"\u009d in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\"\u009d in both areas. Doctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes. The international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\u009d Gaza's health system has nearly collapsed through almost eight months of war. The hospital, which was treating some 700 wounded and sick people before the latest strikes, said Wednesday that one of its two electrical generators had stopped working, threatening its ability to keep operating ventilators and incubators for premature babies. Israel has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins. The military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza. Troops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles. Israel sent troops into Rafah in May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza. ___ Magdy reported from Cairo. ___ Follow AP's coverage at", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "canadian_press@medicinehatnews.com", "name": "Canadian Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNRWA", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "UNRWA"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinians", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Palestinians"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deir_al-Balah", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Deir al-Balah"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Deir al-Balah"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Palestine"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamas", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Hamas"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strike_action", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Strike action"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_Strip", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Internally displaced person"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refugee_camp", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Refugee camp"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinian_refugees", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Palestinian refugees"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temple_Mount", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "8164863619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:28:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:28:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:26:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/news/world/33-killed-as-israeli-army-strikes-hamas-compound-inside-un-school-in-gaza-11717682162119.html", "title": "33 killed as Israeli army strikes 'Hamas compound' inside UN school in Gaza", "body": "At least 33 people were killed after the Israeli army said it had carried out a deadly strike on a UN school in central Gaza on Thursday. The army claimed that the school housed a \"Hamas compound\".\n\nThe Israel Defense Forces posted on X, \"several Hamas and Islamic Jihad terrorists who embedded themselves inside of an @UNRWA school.\" It said, \"IAF fighter jets conducted a precise strike on a Hamas compound embedded inside the school in the area of Nuseirat.\"\n\nThe Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school. It further claimed that the terrorists belonged to the Nukhba Forces and participated in the October 7 massacre. It added that several terrorists were \"eliminated\" in the strike.\n\nThe IDF also clarified that a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike,\" including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nAt least 33 were reported dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, news agency the Associated Press reported while citing the hospital records. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering.\n\nHe said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed was quoted by the Associated Press as saying.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital.\n\nVideos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\nAn Israeli military spokesman, Lt Col Peter Lerner, said that the army wasn't aware of any civilian casualties in the strike. He said that intelligence indicated that militants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on October 7 and that at least 20 militants there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers.\n\nThe military gave no evidence for its claims and released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nThe military said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' October 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nYou are on Mint! India's #1 news destination (Source: Press Gazette). {"uri": "8164723838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:02:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:02:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:02:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/06/israeli-strike-kills-at-least-33-at-gaza-school-the-military-claims-was-being-used-by-hamas/", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 at Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "Palestinians mourn relatives killed in an Israeli strike on Israeli strike on a U.N.-run school in the Nusseirat refugee camp Thursday outside a hospital in Deir al Balah, Gaza Strip. Abdel Kareem Hana/Associated Press\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensives in the Gaza Strip. A day earlier, the military announced a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital - there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nPalestinians look at the aftermath of the Israeli strike on a U.N.-run school that killed dozens of people Thursday in the Nusseirat refugee camp in the Gaza Strip. Abdel Kareem Hana/Associated Press\n\nAn Israeli military spokesman, Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, said that the army wasn't aware of any civilian casualties in the strike. He said that intelligence indicated that militants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on Oct. 7 and that at least 20 militants there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers. The military gave no evidence for its claims and released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nThe miltiary said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas militants. An inferno that followed ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families, killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal. On Wednesday, National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, a leading hard-liner, spoke at an annual march through Jerusalem's Old City, saying, \"We are delivering a message from here to Hamas: Jerusalem is ours. Damascus Gate is ours\" - referring to a main gate into the Arab-majority section of the city - \"And with God's help total victory is ours.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe annual march commemorates \"Jerusalem Day,\" which marks Israel's capture of east Jerusalem, including the Old City and its holy sites sacred to Jews, Christians and Muslims, in the 1967 Middle East war.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nComments are not available on this story.\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\n\" Previous\n\nClimate records keep getting shattered. "news/Politics", "wgt": 88}], "image": "https://www.pressherald.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2024/06/Israel_Palestinians_13963_3b6244-1717678870.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9626324", "eventUri": "eng-9626324", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-10-07", "textStart": 3707, "textEnd": 3713, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": -0.2156862745098039, "wgt": 201, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-380869101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:40:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:40:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T03:45:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/israel-military-says-targeted-hamas-034543644.html", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at a Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at a Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas\n\nWAFAA SHURAFA and SAMY MAGDY\n\nJune 6, 2024 at 2:03 PM\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensives in the Gaza Strip. A day earlier, the military announced a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital -- there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nAn Israeli military spokesman, Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, said that the army wasn't aware of any civilian casualties in the strike. He said that intelligence indicated that militants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on Oct. 7 and that at least 20 militants there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers. The military gave no evidence for its claims and released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nThe military said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas militants. An inferno that followed ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families , killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal. On Wednesday, National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, a leading hard-liner, spoke at an annual march through Jerusalem's Old City, saying, \"We are delivering a message from here to Hamas: Jerusalem is ours. Damascus Gate is ours\" -- referring to a main gate into the Arab-majority section of the city -- \"And with God's help total victory is ours.\"\n\nThe annual march commemorates \"Jerusalem Day,\" which marks Israel's capture of east Jerusalem, including the Old City and its holy sites sacred to Jews, Christians and Muslims, in the 1967 Middle East war.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\n___\n\nSamy Magdy reported from Cairo.\n\n___\n\nFollow AP's coverage at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "samy_magdy@aol.com", "name": "Samy Magdy", "type": "author", The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensive. A day earlier, the military announced a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into parts of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli operations and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital.\n\nVideos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital -- there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nPhilippe Lazzarini, the commissioner-general of UNRWA, said in a post on X that 6,000 people were sheltering in the school when it was hit without prior warning. He said UNRWA was unable to verify claims that armed groups were inside.\n\nAn Israeli military spokesman, Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, said that the army wasn't aware of any civilian casualties in the strike. He said that intelligence indicated that militants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on Oct. 7 and that at least 20 militants there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers. The military gave no evidence for its claims and released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nThe military said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas militants. An inferno ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families , killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. It is a built-up Palestinian refugee camp in central Gaza dating back to the 1948 Arab-Israeli war.\n\nThe Israeli military published a graphic of the school, which clearly had 'UN' written on its roof. The graphic described the strikes targeting two areas of the building on its upper floors.\n\nThe war began with Hamas' October 7 attack inside Israel that killed at least 1,200 people with 250 others taken hostage.\n\nThe Israeli military campaign in the Gaza Strip has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, with hundreds of others killed in operations in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nThe {"uri": "2024-06-380584998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:43:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:43:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:32:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/israeli-strike-kills-at-least-33-people-at-gaza-school-the-military-claims-was-being/article_34c7d00a-23db-567d-ab7c-138f381ebd13.html", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensives in the Gaza Strip. A day earlier, the military announced a a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital -- there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" within the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops, though it didn't immediately offer evidence. It released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas militants. An inferno that followed ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families , killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal. On Wednesday, National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, a leading hard-liner, spoke at an annual march through Jerusalem's Old City, saying, \"We are delivering a message from here to Hamas: Jerusalem is ours. Damascus Gate is ours\" -- referring to a main gate into the Arab-majority section of the city -- \"And with God's help total victory is ours.\"\n\nThe annual march commemorates \"Jerusalem Day,\" which marks Israel's capture of east Jerusalem, including the Old City and its holy sites sacred to Jews, Christians and Muslims, in the 1967 Middle East war.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nSamy Magdy reported from Cairo.\n\nFollow AP's coverage at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war\n\nMore from this section\n\nRyan Zinke wins Republican nomination for U.S. House in Montana's 1st Congressional District\n\nImaget v2.0.0 Released: Bulk {"uri": "8164032700", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:38:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:38:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:37:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-kills-30-people/article68257939.ece", "title": "Israeli strike on Gaza school kills 30 people", "body": "An Israeli strike early on June 6 on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military said was being used as a \"Hamas compound\" killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza and an international medical group reported soaring casualties. The latest operations appear to mark a widening of Israel's nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack.\n\nAlso read | UNICEF finds 90% of Gaza's children lack food needed for proper growth\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run media had earlier reported a higher toll from the strike on the school.\n\nThe Israeli military said its fighter jets struck the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known by the acronym UNRWA. The Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations.\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has displaced most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians.\n\n\"Before the strike, a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike, including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information,\" the Israeli military said.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating back to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nThe latest war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael steps up military offensive in Gaza as US presses for ceasefire\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\n\nGaza's health system has nearly collapsed through almost eight months of war. The hospital, which was treating some 700 wounded and sick people before the latest strikes, said Wednesday that one of its two electrical generators had stopped working, threatening its ability to keep operating ventilators and incubators for premature babies.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah last month in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.\n\nWatch | Israel's Rafah invasion | Explained Read Comments", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8164234967", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:06:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:06:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:05:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/2024/06/06/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-supposedly-used-by-hamas-kills-more-than-30", "title": "Israeli strike on Gaza school 'used by Hamas' kills more than 30", "body": "The Israeli military has not yet offered evidence for its claim that Hamas and other Jihadi militants were plotting attacks from a 'compound' within the building.\n\nAn Israeli strike on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike on early Thursday morning came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA).\n\nThe school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nThe Israeli military claimed Hamas militants were operating from within the school, but has yet to offer evidence.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floors where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open.\n\n\"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records.\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, described chaotic scenes outside the facility. He said vehicles arrived one after the other, as distressed people rushed wounded people into the emergency department. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards.\n\nAl-Kareem said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" within the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops, though it did not immediately offer evidence. It released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.\n\nThe US has thrown its weight behind a phased ceasefire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. {"uri": "8165080595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:56:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:56:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:55:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.sentinelandenterprise.com/2024/06/06/israeli-strike-kills-at-least-33-people-at-a-gaza-school-the-military-claims-was-being-used-by-hamas/", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at a Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "By WAFAA SHURAFA and SAMY MAGDY (Associated Press)\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas was operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensive. A day earlier, the military announced a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas fighters it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into parts of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught.\n\nHamas has been designated as a terrorist organization by the United States, Canada and the European Union.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli operations and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from the school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital.\n\nVideos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital -- there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nPhilippe Lazzarini, the commissioner-general of UNRWA, said in a post on X that 6,000 people were sheltering in the school when it was hit without prior warning. He said UNRWA was unable to verify claims that armed groups were inside.\n\nAn Israeli military spokesman, Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, said that the army wasn't aware of any civilian casualties in the strike. He said that intelligence indicated that combatants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on Oct. 7 and that at least 20 fighters there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers. The military gave no evidence for its claims and released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed combatants were located.\n\nThe military said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas. An inferno ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families , killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which combatants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.", "source": {"uri": "sentinelandenterprise.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sentinel {"uri": "8164202498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:50:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:50:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:44:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13500835/Israeli-strike-kills-30-people-Gaza-school-used-Hamas.html", "title": "Israeli strike kills more than 30 people at Gaza school 'being used...", "body": "An Israeli strike on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza has killed more than 30 people including 23 women and children, according to health officials.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from the school in Nuseirat.\n\nThe strike on Thursday came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing militants it says have regrouped there.\n\nPalestinians look for their relatives killed in the Israeli bombardment (Abdel Kareem Hana/AP)\n\nIt is the latest instance of troops sweeping back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the pre-dawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known as UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital.\n\nAnother strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nOnline footage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital, which was largely dark as staff try to conserve limited fuel for electricity.\n\nPalestinians mourn in front of the morgue of Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah (Abdel Kareem Hana/AP)\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among the bodies, adding: \"The situation is tragic.\"\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" in the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops.\n\nIt released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nIt said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information\".\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas's October 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage.\n\nDisplaced Palestinians inspect their tents destroyed by Israel\u00b4s bombardment of an UNRWA facility west of Rafah city (Jehad Alshrafi/AP)\n\nIsrael's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe US has thrown its weight behind a phased ceasefire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week, but Israel says it will not end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting ceasefire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said on Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with air strikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were taken to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said on Wednesday {"uri": "2024-06-380414240", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:52:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:52:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:42:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://kion546.com/ap-national/2024/06/05/israeli-strike-on-gaza-school-that-military-says-was-being-used-by-hamas-kills-30-people/", "title": "An Israeli strike on a Gaza school that the military claims was being used by Hamas kills 30 people - KION546", "body": "DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military claimed was being used as a Hamas compound killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza in an apparent widening of its nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack. An international medical charity had reported soaring casualties even before Thursday's strike.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run TV had earlier reported a higher toll.\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, described chaotic scenes outside the facility. He said vehicles arrived one after the other, as distressed people rushed wounded people into the emergency department. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards.\n\nLater, he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies wrapped in white shrouds in the hospital courtyard. He said one woman kept asking medical workers to open them up to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nThe Israeli military said its fighter jets struck the school that it claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used as cover for their operations.\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has displaced most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians.\n\n\"Before the strike, a number of steps were taken to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians during the strike, including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information,\" the Israeli military said.\n\nBoth strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating back to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nThe latest war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael says it takes measures to avoid harming civilians and blames their deaths of Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas. The military rarely comments on individual strikes, which often kill women and children.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nThe military said Wednesday that forces were operating \"both above and below ground\" in eastern parts of Deir al-Balah and the Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza. It said the operation began with airstrikes on militant infrastructure, after which troops began a \"targeted daylight operation\" in both areas.\n\nDoctors Without Borders said at least 70 bodies and 300 wounded people, mostly women and children, were brought to a hospital in central Gaza on Tuesday and Wednesday after a wave of Israeli strikes.\n\nThe international charity said Wednesday in a post on X that Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital is struggling to treat \"a huge influx of patients, many of them arriving with severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures, and other traumatic injuries.\"\n\nGaza's health system has nearly collapsed through almost eight months of war. The hospital, which was treating some 700 wounded and sick people before the latest strikes, said Wednesday that one of its two electrical generators had stopped working, threatening its ability to keep operating ventilators and incubators for premature babies.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of Gaza's southernmost city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, with many heading toward central Gaza.", "source": {"uri": "kion546.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KION546"}, It is a built-up Palestinian refugee camp in central Gaza dating back to the 1948 Arab-Israeli war.\n\nThe Israeli military published a graphic of the school, which clearly had \"UN\" on its roof. The graphic described the strikes targeting two areas of the building on its upper floors.\n\nThe war began with Hamas' 7 October attack inside Israel that killed at least 1,200 people with 250 others {"uri": "8164969508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:37:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:37:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:36:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/jun/06/israeli-strike-kills-at-least-33-people-at-a-gaza/", "title": "Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at a Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas", "body": "By Wafaa Shurafa and Samy Magdy, Associated Press\n\nThursday, June 6, 2024 | 8:27 a.m.\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said that Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nIt was the latest instance of mass casualties among Palestinians trying to find refuge as Israel expands its offensive. A day earlier, the military announced a new ground and air assault in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. Troops repeatedly have swept back into parts of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli operations and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nCasualties from school strike arrived at the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, which had already been overwhelmed by a stream of constant ambulances since the central Gaza incursion began 24 hours earlier, said Omar al-Derawi, a photographer working for the hospital.\n\nVideos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards. Electricity in much of the hospital is out because staff are rationing fuel supplies for the generator.\n\n\"You can't walk in the hospital -- there's so many people. Women from the victims' families are massed in the hallways, crying,\" he said.\n\nHospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital recorded at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital. Mohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nPhilippe Lazzarini, the commissioner-general of UNRWA, said in a post on X that 6,000 people were sheltering in the school when it was hit without prior warning. He said UNRWA was unable to verify claims that armed groups were inside.\n\nAn Israeli military spokesman, Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, said that the army wasn't aware of any civilian casualties in the strike. He said that intelligence indicated that militants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on Oct. 7 and that at least 20 militants there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers. The military gave no evidence for its claims and released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located.\n\nThe military said it took steps before the strike \"to reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians ... including conducting aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence information.\"\n\nUNRWA schools across Gaza have functioned as shelters since the start of the war, which has driven most of the territory's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes.\n\nLast week, Israeli strikes hit near an UNRWA facility in the southern city of Rafah, saying they were targeting Hamas militants. An inferno ripped through tents nearby housing displaced families , killing at least 45 people. The deaths triggered international outrage, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\" The military said the fire may have been caused by secondary explosions. The cause of the explosions has not been determined.\n\nIsrael sent troops into Rafah in early May in what it said was a limited incursion, but those forces are now operating in central parts of the city. More than 1 million people have fled Rafah since the start of the operation, scattering across southern and central Gaza into new tent camps or crowding into schools and homes.\n\nIsrael launched its campaign in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack into Israel, in which militants killed some 1,200 people and took another 250 hostage. Israel's offensive has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its figures.\n\nIsrael blames civilian deaths on Hamas because it positions fighters, tunnels and rocket launchers in residential areas.\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind a phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by President Joe Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal.\n\nIsrael has routinely launched airstrikes in all parts of Gaza since the start of the war and has carried out massive ground operations in the territory's two largest cities, Gaza City and Khan Younis, that left much of them in ruins.\n\nThe military waged an offensive earlier this year for several weeks in Bureij and several other nearby refugee camps in central Gaza.\n\nTroops pulled out of the Jabaliya camp in northern Gaza last Friday after weeks of fighting caused widespread destruction. First responders have recovered the bodies of 360 people, mostly women and children, killed during the battles.\n\n___\n\nSamy Magdy reported from Cairo.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com",
