{"uri": "8165087485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:01:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:01:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:00:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2024/06/gaza-hospital-says-37-dead-strike-un-school-israel-says-used-hamas", "title": "Gaza hospital says 37 dead in strike on UN school Israel says used by Hamas", "body": "Palestinians at a UN-run school hit during Irsaeli bombradment in central Gaza's Nuseirat - Bashar TALEB\n\nA Gaza hospital said at least 37 people were killed in an Israeli strike Thursday on a UN-run school that the Israeli military alleged housed a \"Hamas compound\".\n\nThe raid came after US, Qatari and Egyptian mediators resumed talks aimed at securing a truce and hostage-prisoner swap in the nearly eight-month war triggered by Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nThe military said it had \"eliminated\" several militants in a \"precise strike on a Hamas compound embedded inside an UNRWA school\" just before 2:00 am in the Nuseirat area of central Gaza.\n\nIsrael accuses Hamas and its allies in Gaza of using schools, hospitals and other civilian infrastructure including facilities run by UNRWA, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, as operational centres -- charges the militants deny.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, near Nuseirat, said it had received the bodies of at least \"37 martyrs\" from the strike.\n\nAn AFP photographer saw Palestinians removing blood-stained mattresses and examining damage to the school where displaced Gazans had been sheltering, parts of it littered with broken concrete slabs.\n\nFaisal Thari, a displaced Gazan who had sought refuge in the school, told AFP: \"Why? What have we done for them to bomb us?\n\n\"We've fled from place to place. There is no safe place. No UNRWA school is safe. No tent is safe. There is no safe place.\"\n\nHamas in a statement decried a \"new crime... against our people\", urging international pressure on Israel to stop \"these brutal massacres\".\n\nThe EU's foreign policy chief Josep Borrell called for the strike to be \"independently investigated\".\n\nA medic at the hospital said another Israeli pre-dawn strike killed six people in a house in Nuseirat refugee camp, while witnesses reported intense shelling in the Bureij and Al-Maghazi camps in the same area.\n\nIsraeli warplanes also carried out strikes in parts of Rafah, a source in Gaza's southernmost city told AFP.\n\n- Spain joins ICJ case -\n\nThe military said troops killed three suspects who had tried to breach the Gaza border fence in the Rafah area, adding no militants had crossed into Israel.\n\nIt also said a soldier was killed in Gaza on Thursday, bringing to 295 the overall death toll since the start of its ground offensive in the Palestinian territory on October 27.\n\nThe war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack, which resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 251 hostages, 120 of whom remain in Gaza, including 41 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military offensive has killed at least 36,654 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to the Hamas-run territory's health ministry.\n\nAs the fighting has raged on, Israel has faced growing diplomatic isolation, with international court cases accusing it of war crimes and several European countries recognising a Palestinian state.\n\nSpain, which last week sparked Israeli fury by formally recognising Palestinian statehood, said Thursday it would become the latest country to join South Africa's case at the International Court of Justice accusing Israel of \"genocide\" against Palestinians in Gaza.\n\nForeign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said Madrid's \"sole goal is to put an end to the war and to advance\" a two-state solution to the conflict.\n\n- Peace push -\n\nUS President Joe Biden last week outlined what he called a three-phase Israeli plan to halt the fighting for six weeks while hostages are exchanged for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails and the delivery of aid into Gaza is stepped up.\n\nG7 powers and Arab states have backed the proposal and on Wednesday 16 world leaders including key European and Latin American players signed alongside Biden calling for Hamas to accept the deal.\n\n\"There is no time to lose. We call on Hamas to close this agreement,\" said the statement issued by the White House.\n\nMajor sticking points remain, however, with Hamas insisting on a permanent truce and full Israeli withdrawal -- demands Israel has rejected.\n\nEgypt's state-linked Al-Qahera news quoted a high-level source on Thursday saying that Cairo had \"received positive signs from the Palestinian movement signalling its aspiration for a ceasefire\".\n\nThe unnamed source said a response was expected from the militant group in the coming days.\n\nMeanwhile, the White House's Middle East coordinator Brett McGurk met Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry in Cairo where the two discussed the talks.\n\nHamas has accused Israel of dragging its feet in the negotiations, and leader Ismail Haniyeh said the Islamist movement would \"deal seriously and positively\" with any offer meeting its key demands.\n\n- Lebanon 'escalation' -\n\nThe war has sent regional tensions soaring, with violence on the rise involving Israel and its allies on the one hand, and Iran-backed armed groups on the other.\n\nRegular cross-border clashes between Israeli forces and Lebanon's Hezbollah movement, which have forced mass evacuations on both sides, have intensified in recent days.\n\nThe Israeli military on Thursday announced a soldier was killed in a Hezbollah drone strike the day before on the town of Hurfeish.\n\nIsraeli politicians have threatened more intense fighting against Hezbollah, which last fought a major war with Israel in 2006.\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday said Israel was \"prepared for a very intense operation\" along the border with Lebanon and that \"one way or another, we will restore security to the north\".\n\nThe United States appeared to warn Israel against acting, with State Department spokesman Matthew Miller saying any \"escalation\" in Lebanon would \"greatly harm Israel's overall security\".", "source": {"uri": "al-monitor.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8164695812", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:46:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:46:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:44:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/world/mid-east/israel-kills-40-palestinians-in-airstrike-on-gaza-unrwa-school", "title": "Israel kills 40 Palestinians in airstrike on Gaza UNRWA school", "body": "Israel killed at least 40 displaced Palestinians Thursday when it targeted a school housing thousands of displaced Gazans at the Nuseirat refugee camp, local authorities said.\n\nIn a statement, the Gaza-based government Media Office said the Israeli army struck a U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees (UNRWA) school in the Nuseirat refugee camp also leaving dozens of people injured.\n\nIt added that the Israeli army's relentless \"massacres\" in Gaza is proof that it continues the \"genocide\" of displaced Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.\n\nAuthorities at Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital said that the attack left at least 40 people dead and dozens of others injured. They said the death toll may rise as victims are still being brought to the hospital.\n\nThe Israeli army, for its part, admitted hitting the UNRWA school in the Nuseirat refugee camp, claiming Hamas fighters were hiding inside.\n\nThe strike took place at a sensitive moment in mediated negotiations on a cease-fire agreement entailing the release of hostages seized by Hamas on Oct. 7 and some of the Palestinians held in Israeli jails. Hamas seeks a permanent end to the war. Israel says it must destroy the resistance group first.\n\nThe United States issued a joint statement with other countries Thursday calling on Israel and Hamas to make whatever compromises were necessary to finalize a deal as the two sides gave contradictory accounts of the school attack.\n\nIsmail al-Thawabta, the director of the government media office, rejected Israel's assertion that the U.N. school in Nuseirat, in central Gaza, had hidden a Hamas command post.\n\n\"The occupation uses ... false fabricated stories to justify the brutal crime it conducted against dozens of displaced people,\" Thawabta told Reuters.\n\nIsrael's military said its fighter jets had carried out a \"precise strike\" and circulated satellite photos highlighting two parts of a building where it said the fighters were based.\n\n\"We're very confident in the intelligence,\" military spokesperson Lt Col. Peter Lerner told a briefing with reporters, accusing Hamas and Islamic Jihad members of deliberately using U.N. facilities as operational bases.\n\nHe alleged 20-30 members were located in the compound and many of them had been killed, but had no precise details as intelligence assessments were being carried out.\n\n\"I'm not aware of any civilian casualties and I'd be very, very cautious of accepting anything that Hamas puts out,\" he said.\n\nThe school, run by the U.N. Palestinian refugee agency (UNRWA), may have been hit several times, said the agency's communications director, Juliette Touma.\n\nShe said she could not confirm the death toll at this stage. Local media had earlier put the toll at 35-40. Thawabta and a medical source said 40 had been killed, including 14 children and nine women.\n\nIsrael announced a new military campaign in central Gaza on Wednesday. It says there will be no halt to fighting during cease-fire talks, which have intensified since U.S. President Joe Biden outlined a proposal on Friday.\n\nSince a weeklong truce in November, all attempts to arrange a cease-fire have failed, with each side blaming the other.\n\n\"At this decisive moment, we call on the leaders of Israel as well as Hamas to make whatever final compromises are necessary to close this deal,\" said the statement issued by the White House jointly with Argentina, Austria, Brazil, Britain, Canada and others.\n\nCIA Director William Burns met senior officials from mediators Qatar and Egypt on Wednesday in Doha to discuss the cease-fire proposal. Two Egyptian security sources said talks continued Thursday but had shown no sign of breakthrough.\n\nBiden has repeatedly declared that cease-fires were close over the past several months, only for no truce to materialize.\n\nLast week's high-profile announcement coincides with intense domestic political pressure on Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to chart a path to end the eight-month-old war and negotiate the release of Israeli captives held by Hamas.\n\nThe conflict was triggered by the Oct. 7 Hamas incursion, which resulted in the death of more than 1,170 people in Israel, according to an AFP tally based on official Israeli figures.\n\nOut of 252 people taken hostage that day, 128 are still being held inside the Gaza Strip, including at least 37 who the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael has killed over 36,600 Palestinians, mostly women and children, in the Gaza Strip since, according to the Gazan Health Ministry\n\nAbout half of Hamas' forces have been wiped out in eight months of fighting, U.S. and Israeli officials told Reuters.\n\nHamas has been reduced to 9,000 to 12,000 fighters, according to three senior U.S. officials familiar with battlefield developments, down from American estimates of 20,000-25,000 before the conflict. Israel says it has lost almost 300 troops in the Gaza campaign.\n\nMeanwhile, Israel on Thursday mounted attack on southern Lebanon, where Hezbollah is based, with the U.S. State Department warning against a full-blown war.\n\nAlthough Biden described the cease-fire proposal as an Israeli offer, Israel's government has been lukewarm in public. A top Netanyahu aide confirmed Sunday that Israel had made the proposal even though it was \"not a good deal.\"\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have pledged to quit if he agrees to a peace deal that leaves Hamas in place, a move that could force a new election and end the political career of Israel's longest-serving leader.\n\nCentrist opponents who joined Netanyahu's war cabinet in a show of unity at the outset of the conflict have also threatened to quit, saying his government has no plan.", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Sabah"}, {"uri": "8165071580", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:49:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:49:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:48:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/gaza-hospital-says-37-dead-in-strike-on-un-school-israel-says-used-by-hamas/articleshow/110774489.cms", "title": "Gaza hospital says 37 dead in strike on UN school Israel says used by Hamas", "body": "A Gaza hospital said at least 37 people were killed in an Israeli strike Thursday on a UN-run school that the Israeli military alleged housed a \"Hamas compound\".\n\nThe raid came after US, Qatari and Egyptian mediators resumed talks aimed at securing a truce and hostage-prisoner swap in the nearly eight-month war triggered by Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nThe military said it had \"eliminated\" several militants in a \"precise strike on a Hamas compound embedded inside an UNRWA school\" just before 2:00 am in the Nuseirat area of central Gaza.\n\nIsrael accuses Hamas and its allies in Gaza of using schools, hospitals and other civilian infrastructure including facilities run by UNRWA, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, as operational centres -- charges the militants deny.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, near Nuseirat, said it had received the bodies of at least \"37 martyrs\" from the strike.\n\nAn photographer saw Palestinians removing blood-stained mattresses and examining damage to the school where displaced Gazans had been sheltering, parts of it littered with broken concrete slabs.\n\nFaisal Thari, a displaced Gazan who had sought refuge in the school, told AFP: \"Why? What have we done for them to bomb us?\n\n\"We've fled from place to place. There is no safe place. No UNRWA school is safe. No tent is safe. There is no safe place.\"\n\nHamas in a statement decried a \"new crime... against our people\", urging international pressure on Israel to stop \"these brutal massacres\".\n\nThe EU's foreign policy chief Josep Borrell called for the strike to be \"independently investigated\".\n\nA medic at the hospital said another Israeli pre-dawn strike killed six people in a house in Nuseirat refugee camp, while witnesses reported intense shelling in the Bureij and Al-Maghazi camps in the same area.\n\nIsraeli warplanes also carried out strikes in parts of Rafah, a source in Gaza's southernmost city told AFP.\n\n- Spain joins ICJ case -\n\nThe military said troops killed three suspects who had tried to breach the Gaza border fence in the Rafah area, adding no militants had crossed into Israel.\n\nIt also said a soldier was killed in Gaza on Thursday, bringing to 295 the overall death toll since the start of its ground offensive in the Palestinian territory on October 27.\n\nThe war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack, which resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 251 hostages, 120 of whom remain in Gaza, including 41 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military offensive has killed at least 36,654 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to the Hamas-run territory's health ministry.\n\nAs the fighting has raged on, Israel has faced growing diplomatic isolation, with international court cases accusing it of war crimes and several European countries recognising a Palestinian state.\n\nSpain, which last week sparked Israeli fury by formally recognising Palestinian statehood, said Thursday it would become the latest country to join South Africa's case at the International Court of Justice accusing Israel of \"genocide\" against Palestinians in Gaza.\n\nForeign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said Madrid's \"sole goal is to put an end to the war and to advance\" a two-state solution to the conflict.\n\n- Peace push -\n\nUS President Joe Biden last week outlined what he called a three-phase Israeli plan to halt the fighting for six weeks while hostages are exchanged for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails and the delivery of aid into Gaza is stepped up.\n\nG7 powers and Arab states have backed the proposal and on Wednesday 16 world leaders including key European and Latin American players signed alongside Biden calling for Hamas to accept the deal.\n\n\"There is no time to lose. We call on Hamas to close this agreement,\" said the statement issued by the White House.\n\nMajor sticking points remain, however, with Hamas insisting on a permanent truce and full Israeli withdrawal -- demands Israel has rejected.\n\nEgypt's state-linked Al-Qahera news quoted a high-level source on Thursday saying that Cairo had \"received positive signs from the Palestinian movement signalling its aspiration for a ceasefire\".\n\nThe unnamed source said a response was expected from the militant group in the coming days.\n\nMeanwhile, the White House's Middle East coordinator Brett McGurk met Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry in Cairo where the two discussed the talks.\n\nHamas has accused Israel of dragging its feet in the negotiations, and leader Ismail Haniyeh said the Islamist movement would \"deal seriously and positively\" with any offer meeting its key demands.\n\n- Lebanon 'escalation' -\n\nThe war has sent regional tensions soaring, with violence on the rise involving Israel and its allies on the one hand, and Iran-backed armed groups on the other.\n\nRegular cross-border clashes between Israeli forces and Lebanon's Hezbollah movement, which have forced mass evacuations on both sides, have intensified in recent days.\n\nThe Israeli military on Thursday announced a soldier was killed in a Hezbollah drone strike the day before on the town of Hurfeish.\n\nIsraeli politicians have threatened more intense fighting against Hezbollah, which last fought a major war with Israel in 2006.\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday said Israel was \"prepared for a very intense operation\" along the border with Lebanon and that \"one way or another, we will restore security to the north\".\n\nThe United States appeared to warn Israel against acting, with State Department spokesman Matthew Miller saying any \"escalation\" in Lebanon would \"greatly harm Israel's overall security\".", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNRWA", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8164789820", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:42:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:42:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:41:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.justiceinfo.net/en/132814-gaza-hospital-says-37-dead-in-strike-on-un-school-israel-says-used-by-hamas.html", "title": "Gaza hospital says 37 dead in strike on UN school Israel says used by Hamas", "body": "A Gaza hospital said at least 37 people were killed in an Israeli strike Thursday on a UN-run school that the Israeli military alleged housed a \"Hamas compound\".\n\nThe raid came after US, Qatari and Egyptian mediators resumed talks aimed at securing a truce and hostage-prisoner swap in the nearly eight-month war triggered by Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nThe military said it had \"eliminated\" several militants in a \"precise strike on a Hamas compound embedded inside an UNRWA school\" just before 2:00 am in the Nuseirat area of central Gaza.\n\nIsrael accuses Hamas and its allies in Gaza of using schools, hospitals and other civilian infrastructure including facilities run by UNRWA, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, as operational centres -- charges the militants deny.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, near Nuseirat, said it had received the bodies of at least \"37 martyrs\" from the strike.\n\nAn AFP photographer saw Palestinians removing blood-stained mattresses and examining damage to the school where displaced Gazans had been sheltering, parts of it littered with broken concrete slabs.\n\nHamas in a statement decried a \"new crime... against our people\", urging international pressure on Israel to stop \"these brutal massacres\".\n\nA medic at the hospital said another Israeli pre-dawn strike killed six people in a house in Nuseirat refugee camp, while witnesses reported intense shelling in the Bureij and Al-Maghazi camps in the same area.\n\nIsraeli warplanes also carried out strikes in parts of Rafah, a source in Gaza's southernmost city told AFP.\n\n- Spain joins ICJ case -\n\nThe military said troops killed three suspects who had tried to breach the Gaza border fence in the Rafah area, adding no militants had crossed into Israel.\n\nIt also said a soldier was killed in Gaza on Thursday, bringing to 295 the overall death toll since the start of its ground offensive in the Palestinian territory on October 27.\n\nThe war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack, which resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 251 hostages, 120 of whom remain in Gaza, including 41 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military offensive has killed at least 36,654 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to the Hamas-run territory's health ministry.\n\nSixty-eight of them were killed in the past 24 hours, the ministry said.\n\nAs the fighting has raged on, Israel has faced growing diplomatic isolation, with international court cases accusing it of war crimes and several European countries recognising a Palestinian state.\n\nSpain, which last week sparked Israeli fury by formally recognising Palestinian statehood, said Thursday it would become the latest country to join South Africa's case at the International Court of Justice accusing Israel of \"genocide\" against Palestinians in Gaza.\n\nForeign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said Madrid's \"sole goal is to put an end to the war and to advance\" a two-state solution to the conflict.\n\n- 'Tired and exhausted' -\n\nThe situation on the ground remains dire for people like Muhammad al-Najjar, a 35-year-old man from northern Gaza twice displaced by the war.\n\n\"As far as we are concerned, we are tired and exhausted. We just want to... end the catastrophic situation that we are living,\" he told AFP.\n\nUS President Joe Biden last week outlined what he called a three-phase Israeli plan to halt the fighting for six weeks while hostages are exchanged for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails and the delivery of aid into Gaza is stepped up.\n\nG7 powers and Arab states have backed the proposal. Major sticking points remain, however, with Hamas insisting on a permanent truce and full Israeli withdrawal -- demands Israel has rejected.\n\nA source with knowledge of the negotiations told AFP senior Qatari and Egyptian officials met Hamas representatives in Doha on Wednesday \"to discuss a deal for a truce in Gaza and the exchange of hostages and prisoners\".\n\nBiden has sent CIA chief Bill Burns to Qatar, where Hamas's political office is based, for a renewed push after months of stalled negotiations.\n\nHamas has accused Israel of dragging its feet in the talks, and leader Ismail Haniyeh said the Islamist movement would \"deal seriously and positively\" with any offer meeting its key demands.\n\nSuhail al-Hindi, a Hamas official, said there would be \"no agreement\" without \"a ceasefire and the withdrawal of the (Israeli) occupation\".\n\n\"The ball is in the occupation's court, and we await their response.\"\n\n- Lebanon 'escalation' -\n\nThe war has sent regional tensions soaring, with violence on the rise involving Israel and its allies on the one hand, and Iran-backed armed groups on the other.\n\nRegular cross-border clashes between Israeli forces and Lebanon's Hezbollah movement, which have forced mass evacuations on both sides, have intensified in recent days, causing more deaths and igniting wildfires.\n\nThe Israeli military on Thursday announced a soldier was killed in a Hezbollah drone strike the day before on the town of Hurfeish.\n\nIsraeli politicians have threatened more intense fighting against Hezbollah, which last fought a major war with Israel in 2006.\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday said Israel was \"prepared for a very intense operation\" along the border with Lebanon and that \"one way or another, we will restore security to the north\".\n\nThe United States appeared to warn Israel against taking action, with State Department spokesman Matthew Miller saying any \"escalation\" in Lebanon would {"uri": "8164396887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:47:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:47:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:46:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.wivb.com/news/ap-the-latest-over-30-dead-in-israeli-strikes-overnight-in-gaza-including-on-a-school-turned-shelter/", "title": "The Latest | Over 30 dead in Israeli strikes overnight in Gaza, including on a school-turned-shelter", "body": "Dozens are dead after an Israeli strike hit a school-turned-shelter in Gaza overnight. Israel claimed Thursday the school was being used as a Hamas compound, without providing evidence.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home.\n\nInternational pressure has been mounting to limit civilian bloodshed in the Israel-Hamas war. Spain's foreign minister announced Thursday that the country would ask a United Nations court for permission to join South Africa's case accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza. United States President Joe Biden's administration has launched an intense drive to persuade Hamas and Israel to accept a new cease-fire and hostage release proposal, which has raised hopes of ending the war.\n\nIsrael's war against Hamas in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe eight-month war in Gaza has largely cut off the flow of food, medicine and other supplies to Palestinians who are facing widespread hunger. United Nations agencies say over 1 million in Gaza could experience the highest level of starvation by mid-July.\n\nIsrael launched the war after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack, in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Around 80 hostages captured on Oct. 7 are believed to still be alive in Gaza, alongside the remains of 43 others.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Israeli strike on a Gaza school that military says was being used by Hamas kills 30 people.\n\n-- Spain applies to join South Africa's case at top the U.N. court accusing Israel of genocide.\n\n-- One image, millions of eyeballs: A social media effort to draw attention to Rafah surges.\n\n-- Israeli settlers in the West Bank were hit with international sanctions. It only emboldened them.\n\n-- Yemen's Houthi rebels unveil solid-fuel 'Palestine' missile that resembles Iranian hypersonic.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nMADRID -- Spain will ask a United Nations court for permission to join South Africa's case accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza, its foreign minister announced Thursday.\n\nSpain is the first European country to take the step after South Africa filed its case with the International Court of Justice in late 2023. It alleged that Israel was breaching the genocide convention in its military assault that has laid waste to large swaths of Gaza.\n\nMexico, Colombia, Nicaragua, Libya and the Palestinians have already requested to join the case currently being heard at the court in The Hague, Netherlands.\n\nThe court has ordered Israel to immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah but stopped short of ordering a cease-fire for the enclave. Israel has not complied.\n\nSpain's request to join the case is the latest move by the government of Socialist Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez to support peacemaking efforts in Gaza.\n\nIsrael denies it is committing genocide in its military operation to crush Hamas triggered by its deadly Oct. 7 attacks in southern Israel.\n\nHamas killed 1,200 people and took 250 more hostage in the surprise attacks. Israel's air and land attacks have killed 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military claimed was being used as a Hamas compound killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza in an apparent widening of its nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack. An international medical charity had reported soaring casualties even before Thursday's strike.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run TV had earlier reported a higher toll.\n\nThe Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations and that risk reduction steps were taken before the strike.\n\nThe war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack inside Israel that killed at least 1,200 people with 250 others taken hostage. The Israeli military campaign in the Gaza Strip has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, with hundreds of others killed in operations in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Yemen's Houthi rebels have unveiled a new, solid-fuel missile in their arsenal that resembles aspects of one earlier displayed by Iran that Tehran described as flying at hypersonic speeds.\n\nThe rebels fired their new \"Palestine\" missile, complete with a warhead painted like a Palestinian keffiyeh checkered scarf, at the southern Gulf of Aqaba port of Eilat in Israel on Monday. The attack set off air raid sirens but caused no reported damage or injuries.\n\nFootage released by the Houthis late Wednesday showed the Palestine being raised on what appeared to be a mobile launcher and rising quickly into the air with plumes of white smoke coming from its engine. White smoke is common with solid-fuel missiles.\n\nSolid-fuel missiles can be set up and fired faster than those containing liquid fuel. That's a key concern for the Houthis as their missile launch sites have been repeatedly targeted by U.S. and allied forces in recent months over the rebels' attacks on shipping through the Red Sea corridor. One such strike hit the Houthis even before they were able to launch their missile.", "source": {"uri": "wivb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "wivb4"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": What have we done for them to bomb us?\n\n\"We've fled from place to place. There is no safe place. No UNRWA school is safe. No tent is safe. There is no safe place.\"\n\nHamas in a statement decried a \"new crime... against our people\", urging international pressure on Israel to stop \"these brutal massacres\".\n\nThe EU's foreign policy chief Josep Borrell called for the strike to be \"independently investigated\".\n\nA medic at the hospital said another Israeli pre-dawn strike killed six people in a house in Nuseirat refugee camp, while witnesses reported intense shelling in the Bureij and Al-Maghazi camps in the same area.\n\nIsraeli warplanes also carried out strikes in parts of Rafah, a source in Gaza's southernmost city told AFP.\n\n- Spain joins ICJ case -\n\nThe military said troops killed three suspects who had tried to breach the Gaza border fence in the Rafah area, adding no militants had crossed into Israel.\n\nIt also said a soldier was killed in Gaza on Thursday, bringing to 295 the overall death toll since the start of its ground offensive in the Palestinian territory on October 27.\n\nThe war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack, which resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 251 hostages, 120 of whom remain in Gaza, including 41 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military offensive has killed at least 36,654 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to the Hamas-run territory's health ministry.\n\nAs the fighting has raged on, Israel has faced growing diplomatic isolation, with international court cases accusing it of war crimes and several European countries recognising a Palestinian state.\n\nMore from this section Philippines: Kanlaon Volcano Eruption - Lahar Roars Through Town In La Castellana 4 Americans Skeptical About Switching to EVs Amid Challenges Rihanna Unveils Fenty Hair for Diverse Hair Needs\n\nSpain, which last week sparked Israeli fury by formally recognising Palestinian statehood, said Thursday it would become the latest country to join South Africa's case at the International Court of Justice accusing Israel of \"genocide\" against Palestinians in Gaza.\n\nForeign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said Madrid's \"sole goal is to put an end to the war and to advance\" a two-state solution to the conflict.\n\n- Peace push -\n\nUS President Joe Biden last week outlined what he called a three-phase Israeli plan to halt the fighting for six weeks while hostages are exchanged for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails and the delivery of aid into Gaza is stepped up.\n\nG7 powers and Arab states have backed the proposal and on Wednesday 16 world leaders including key European and Latin American players signed alongside Biden calling for Hamas to accept the deal.\n\n\"There is no time to lose. We call on Hamas to close this agreement,\" said the statement issued by the White House.\n\nMajor sticking points remain, however, with Hamas insisting on a permanent truce and full Israeli withdrawal -- demands Israel has rejected.\n\nEgypt's state-linked Al-Qahera news quoted a high-level source on Thursday saying that Cairo had \"received positive signs from the Palestinian movement signalling its aspiration for a ceasefire\".\n\nThe unnamed source said a response was expected from the militant group in the coming days.\n\nMeanwhile, the White House's Middle East coordinator Brett McGurk met Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry in Cairo where the two discussed the talks.\n\nHamas has accused Israel of dragging its feet in the negotiations, and leader Ismail Haniyeh said the Islamist movement would \"deal seriously and positively\" with any offer meeting its key demands.\n\n- Lebanon 'escalation' -\n\nThe war has sent regional tensions soaring, with violence on the rise involving Israel and its allies on the one hand, and Iran-backed armed groups on the other.\n\nRegular cross-border clashes between Israeli forces and Lebanon's Hezbollah movement, which have forced mass evacuations on both sides, have intensified in recent days.\n\nThe Israeli military on Thursday announced a soldier was killed in a Hezbollah drone strike the day before on the town of Hurfeish.\n\nIsraeli politicians have threatened more intense fighting against Hezbollah, which last fought a major war with Israel in 2006.\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday said Israel was \"prepared for a very intense operation\" along the border with Lebanon and that \"one way or another, we will restore security to the north\".\n\nThe United States appeared to warn Israel against acting, with State Department spokesman Matthew Miller saying any \"escalation\" in Lebanon would \"greatly harm Israel's overall security\".\n\nburs-dcp/dv", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", The Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital, which was largely dark as staff tried to conserve limited fuel for electricity.\n\nThe hospital, the nearby town of Deir al-Balah, received at least 37 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to Agence France-Presse, who received the tally from the hospital.\n\nThe strike came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. It's the latest instance of troops sweeping back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" within the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops, though it did not immediately offer evidence. It released a photo of the school, pointing to classrooms on the second and third floor where it claimed militants were located. We have been displaced dozens of times. They killed our children while they were sleeping,\" a woman injured in the attack screamed in one video.\n\nIsmail al-Thawabta, director of the Hamas media office, rejected Israel's claims that the UN school had hidden a Hamas command post.\n\n\"The occupation uses ... false fabricated stories to justify the brutal crime it conducted against dozens of displaced people,\" he told Reuters.\n\nThe Israel Defense Forces (IDF) said jets had conducted a \"precise strike on a Hamas compound embedded inside an UNRWA school in the area of Nuseirat\".\n\nThe IDF statement said it had \"eliminated\" Hamas and Islamic Jihad \"terrorists\" who took part in the 7 October attack on southern Israel, when around 1,200 people were killed and 251 others were taken hostage.\n\nAt least 36,580 people have been killed in Gaza since then, according to the territory's Hamas-run health ministry.\n\nThe IDF said it had taken steps before the air strike to \"reduce the risk of harming uninvolved civilians\".\n\nEarlier, the Israeli military said it had taken \"operational control\" over eastern areas of Bureij refugee camp and the town of Deir al-Balah in central Gaza, as dozens of Palestinians were reported killed.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the military said troops backed by air strikes had begun an operation against \"terrorists and terrorist infrastructure above and below ground\".\n\nResidents reported intense bombardment and the charity M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res (MSF) said at least 70 dead people - the majority women and children - had been brought to a local hospital since Tuesday.\n\nMSF said its medical team on the ground had described the situation at Deir al-Balah's al-Aqsa hospital - one of the only remaining functional health facilities in central Gaza - as \"apocalyptic\".\n\nThe charity said women and children made up the majority of the 70 dead people and 300 wounded, brought to hospital over the past 24 hours, and that many patients were suffering from severe burns, shrapnel wounds, fractures and other traumatic injuries.\n\n\"The odour of blood when I entered the emergency room [this morning] was just overwhelming. People are lying on the floor. People are lying outside... bodies being brought in white plastic bags. The families standing over them and praying,\" MSF medical referent Karin Huster said in an audio message.\n\n\"It's just an emotionally overwhelming situation. {"uri": "8165110542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:18:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:18:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:17:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/the-latest-israeli-strike-kills-33-in-a-gaza-school-filled-with-displaced-families/article_b29423f0-cb25-5773-8dd5-19584ae235a6.html", "title": "The Latest | Israeli strike kills 33 in a Gaza school filled with displaced families", "body": "Not a subscriber? Buy a Day Pass or just this story using our new Digital Wallet\n\nAn Israeli strike in central Gaza killed at least 33 people overnight when it hit a United Nations-run school being sheltering displaced Palestinian families.\n\nIsrael claimed Thursday the school was being used as a Hamas compound, without providing evidence. Israel's military later said it was not aware of any civilian casualties in the strike on the school in Nuseirat refugee camp.\n\nCasualties from the school strike -- including 14 children and nine women -- were taken to a hospital in nearby Deir al-Balah, as documented by hospital records and an Associated Press journalist. The hospital has already been overwhelmed by a stream of ambulances since Israeli forces launched a new offensive in central Gaza this week.\n\nInternational pressure has been mounting on Israel to limit civilian bloodshed in its war against Hamas in Gaza. Spain's foreign minister announced Thursday that the country would ask a United Nations court for permission to join South Africa's case accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza. Israel strongly denies the accusation.\n\nMore than 36,000 Palestinians have been killed by eight months of Israeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, according to the Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe war has largely cut off the flow of food, medicine and other supplies to Palestinians who are facing widespread hunger. United Nations agencies say over 1 million in Gaza could experience the highest level of starvation by mid-July.\n\nIsrael launched the war after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack, in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Around 80 hostages captured on Oct. 7 are believed to still be alive in Gaza, alongside the remains of 43 others.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Israeli strike kills at least 33 people at a Gaza school the military claims was being used by Hamas.\n\n-- Spain applies to join South Africa's case at top the U.N. court accusing Israel of genocide.\n\n-- A social media effort to draw attention to Rafah surges.\n\n-- Israeli settlers in the West Bank were hit with international sanctions. It only emboldened them.\n\n-- Yemen's Houthi rebels unveil solid-fuel 'Palestine' missile that resembles Iranian hypersonic.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nISRAELI FORCES KILL 3 PALESTINIANS IN WEST BANK, HEALTH MINISTRY SAYS\n\nJERUSALEM -- The Palestinian Health Ministry says three Palestinians have been killed by Israeli fire in the occupied West Bank.\n\nThe Israeli military said forces carrying out an arrest raid in the northern West Bank city of Jenin on Thursday opened fire at three individuals who had thrown explosives at them and that a helicopter struck the area. It said the forces also arrested a suspected militant.\n\nViolence has surged in the Israeli-occupied West Bank since Hamas' Oct. 7 attack triggered the war in Gaza. Israel has carried out frequent arrest raids that often ignite gunbattles. Settler violence and Palestinian attacks on Israelis have also been on the rise.\n\nThe Health Ministry, part of the Western-backed Palestinian Authority, says around 530 Palestinians have been killed in the West Bank since the start of the Gaza war.\n\nIsrael captured the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem in the 1967 Mideast war. The Palestinians want all three territories for their future state.\n\nThe 3 million Palestinians in the West Bank live under seemingly open-ended Israeli military rule, while the more than 500,000 Jewish settlers in the territory have Israeli citizenship.\n\nMORE THAN A DOZEN COUNTRIES JOIN U.S. IN STATEMENT SUPPORTING BIDEN'S GAZA PLAN\n\nWASHINGTON -- More than a dozen countries joined the U.S. in a statement Thursday to show support for U.S. President Joe Biden's proposed deal to release the remaining hostages in Gaza and end the grinding Mideast war.\n\nThe statement was signed by the leaders of Argentina, Austria, Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, Colombia, Denmark, France, Germany, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Serbia, Spain, Thailand and the United Kingdom as well as the United States.\n\n\"As leaders of countries deeply concerned for the hostages held by Hamas in Gaza, including many of our own citizens, we fully support the movement towards a ceasefire and hostage release deal now on the table and as outlined by President Biden on May 31, 2024,\" the statement said. \"There is no time to lose.\"\n\nThe United States has thrown its weight behind the phased cease-fire and hostage release outlined by Biden last week. But Israel says it won't end the war without destroying Hamas, while the militant group is demanding a lasting cease-fire and the full withdrawal of Israeli forces.\n\nFar-right members of Netanyahu's government have threatened to bring down the coalition if he signs onto a cease-fire deal.\n\nISRAEL'S MILITARY SAYS IT TRADED FIRE WITH PALESTINIAN MILITANTS JUST YARDS FROM GAZA BORDER\n\nJERUSALEM -- The Israeli military says it traded fire with Palestinian militants in southern Gaza some 300 meters (yards) from the Israeli border.\n\nThe fighters appeared to have infiltrated a heavily guarded buffer zone.\n\nLt. Col. Peter Lerner, an Israeli military spokesman, said the gunbattle erupted before dawn on Thursday. He said two militants were killed from the air and a third in a tank strike.\n\nIsraeli media later reported that an Israeli soldier was killed in the shootout. The military confirmed that a soldier was killed during a confrontation with militants in southern Gaza early Thursday but declined to say whether it was linked to the infiltration attempt.\n\nSatellite photos earlier this year showed extensive demolition inside Gaza along the border. Israel appears to have established a buffer zone despite international objections.\n\nThe United States, which has provided key military aid for Israel's nearly eight-month offensive, has said Gaza's territory should not shrink. Israel says it needs a buffer zone to prevent Hamas from carrying out another attack into southern Israel like the one on Oct. 7 that ignited the war.\n\nISRAEL'S REPRESENTATIVE RESIGNS FROM ICJ JUDGE PANEL OVERSEEING GENOCIDE CASE\n\nJERUSALEM -- Israel's representative on the panel of judges hearing the genocide case against Israel at the world's top court resigned from his post, citing personal reasons, according to a letter he sent to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seen by The Associated Press on Thursday.\n\nJustice Aharon Barak, a former attorney general and peace negotiator who served as chief justice of Israel's highest court from 1995 to 2006, wrote Tuesday to Netanyahu, telling him that he had sent the president of the International Court of Justice a resignation letter.\n\n\"My resignation is for personal and family reasons,\" he wrote to Netanyahu. \"Thank you for the trust placed in me.\"\n\nBarak was one of four justices on the court who said the ICJ's ruling that Israel cease operations in Rafah, Gaza's southernmost city, did not mean Israel needed to stop operations there entirely. He said Israel could still operate in Gaza but needed to avoid causing undue harm to Palestinian civilians and contravening Israel's obligations under the Genocide Convention.\n\nIsraeli President Isaac Herzog, whose position is largely ceremonial, thanked Barak on Thursday for serving on the court in a statement posted to X, adding: \"We will continue to stand firm against the evil, the hypocrisy and the false accusations leveled against the State of Israel and the IDF,\" using an acronym for Israel's military.\n\nRECENT DRONE STRIKE IN NORTHERN ISRAEL KILLED A RESERVE SOLDIER, MILITARY SAYS\n\nJERUSALEM -- Israel's military said Thursday that a drone strike on a village in northern Israel the day before killed an Israeli reserve soldier.\n\nThe Lebanese militant group Hezbollah said it launched an attack toward a gathering of military officials in response to an earlier Israeli cross-border attack.\n\nIsrael's military said two explosive drones were fired toward Hurfeish, a northern village in Israel.\n\nAir raid sirens did not go off ahead of the strike, and Israeli authorities said that the strike wounded over 10 people in addition to the one soldier killed. The military identified the fallen soldier as Staff Sgt. (res.) Refael Kauders, 39.\n\nWith Kaunders' death, 16 soldiers have been killed in Israel's north since October, along with 10 civilians.\n\nMore 400 people have been killed in Lebanon, including more than 70 civilians and noncombatants.\n\nIsrael and Hezbollah have been exchanging fire daily since a day after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack, which set off the war in Gaza. The deadly fighting has displaced tens of thousands of people on both sides of the Israel-Lebanon border and sparked fears of a wider regional war.\n\nISRAELI MILITARY SAYS IT'S NOT AWARE OF ANY CIVILIAN CASUALTIES IN ITS STRIKE ON A SCHOOL\n\nJERUSALEM -- Israel's military said Thursday it was not aware of any civilian casualties in a strike that killed at least 33 Palestinians, including 23 women and children, according to local officials and an AP reporter at the hospital that received the bodies.\n\nThe strike occurred early Thursday on a United Nations school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza. Israeli military spokesperson Lt. Col. Peter Lerner said intelligence indicated that militants had used the school compound to orchestrate some of the attacks on Oct. 7 and that at least 20 militants there were using it currently as a \"staging realm\" to launch attacks on Israeli soldiers.\n\n\"I'm not aware of civilians being caught up in this. We will be looking at the data and intelligence that comes out in the next few hours or day,\" Lerner told journalists.\n\nHe declined to say whether the military would investigate the strike, as it did in May when an Israeli strike nearby a tent camp sheltering displaced people killed dozens in Rafah, Gaza's southernmost city.\n\nSPAIN APPLIES TO JOIN SOUTH AFRICA'S CASE ACCUSING ISRAEL OF GENOCIDE\n\nMADRID -- Spain will ask a United Nations court for permission to join South Africa's case accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza, its foreign minister announced Thursday.\n\nSpain is the first European country to take the step after South Africa filed its case with the International Court of Justice in late 2023. It alleged that Israel was breaching the genocide convention in its military assault that has laid waste to large swaths of Gaza.\n\nMexico, Colombia, Nicaragua, Libya and the Palestinians have already requested to join the case currently being heard at the court in The Hague, Netherlands.\n\nThe court has ordered Israel to immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah but stopped short of ordering a cease-fire for the enclave. Israel has not complied.\n\nSpain's request to join the case is the latest move by the government of Socialist Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez to support peacemaking efforts in Gaza.\n\nIsrael denies it is committing genocide in its military operation to crush Hamas triggered by its deadly Oct. 7 attacks in southern Israel.\n\nHamas killed 1,200 people and took 250 more hostage in the surprise attacks. Israel's air and land attacks have killed 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nISRAELI STRIKE KILLS DOZENS AT A SCHOOL-TURNED-SHELTER IN GAZA\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military claimed was being used as a Hamas compound killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza in an apparent widening of its nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack. An international medical charity had reported soaring casualties even before Thursday's strike.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run TV had earlier reported a higher toll.\n\nThe Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations and that risk reduction steps were taken before the strike.\n\nThe war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack inside Israel that killed at least 1,200 people with 250 others taken hostage. The Israeli military campaign in the Gaza Strip has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, with hundreds of others killed in operations in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nYEMEN'S HOUTHI REBELS UNVEIL A NEW SOLID-FUEL MISSILE\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Yemen's Houthi rebels have unveiled a new, solid-fuel missile in their arsenal that resembles aspects of one earlier displayed by Iran that Tehran described as flying at hypersonic speeds.\n\nThe rebels fired their new \"Palestine\" missile, complete with a warhead painted like a Palestinian keffiyeh checkered scarf, at the southern Gulf of Aqaba port of Eilat in Israel on Monday. The attack set off air raid sirens but caused no reported damage or injuries.\n\nFootage released by the Houthis late Wednesday showed the Palestine being raised on what appeared to be a mobile launcher and rising quickly into the air with plumes of white smoke coming from its engine. White smoke is common with solid-fuel missiles.\n\nSolid-fuel missiles can be set up and fired faster than those containing liquid fuel. That's a key concern for the Houthis as their missile launch sites have been repeatedly targeted by U.S. and allied forces in recent months over the rebels' attacks on shipping through the Red Sea corridor. One such strike hit the Houthis even before they were able to launch their missile.", "source": {"uri": "news-gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News-Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": United Nations agencies say over 1 million in Gaza could experience the highest level of starvation by mid-July.\n\nIsrael launched the war after Hamas\u00b4 Oct. 7 attack, in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people - mostly civilians - and abducted about 250. It only emboldened them.\n\n- Yemen\u00b4s Houthi rebels unveil solid-fuel 'Palestine\u00b4 missile that resembles Iranian hypersonic.\n\nFollow AP\u00b4s coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip - An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military claimed was being used as a Hamas compound killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza in an apparent widening of its nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas\u00b4 Oct. 7 attack. An international medical charity had reported soaring casualties even before Thursday\u00b4s strike.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees - known by the acronym UNRWA - and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run TV had earlier reported a higher toll.\n\nThe Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations and that risk reduction steps were taken before the strike.\n\nThe war began with Hamas\u00b4 Oct. 7 attack inside Israel that killed at least 1,200 people with 250 others taken hostage. The Israeli military campaign in the Gaza Strip has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, with hundreds of others killed in operations in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates - Yemen\u00b4s Houthi rebels have unveiled a new, solid-fuel missile in their arsenal that resembles aspects of one earlier displayed by Iran that Tehran described as flying at hypersonic speeds.\n\nThe rebels fired their new \"Palestine\" missile, complete with a warhead painted like a Palestinian keffiyeh checkered scarf, at the southern Gulf of Aqaba port of Eilat in Israel on Monday. The attack set off air raid sirens but caused no reported damage or injuries.\n\nFootage released by the Houthis late Wednesday showed the Palestine being raised on what appeared to be a mobile launcher and rising quickly into the air with plumes of white smoke coming from its engine. White smoke is common with solid-fuel missiles.\n\nSolid-fuel missiles can be set up and fired faster than those containing liquid fuel. That\u00b4s a key concern for the Houthis as their missile launch sites have been repeatedly targeted by U.S. and allied forces in recent months over the rebels\u00b4 attacks on shipping through the Red Sea corridor. One such strike hit the Houthis even before they were able to launch their missile.\n\nPalestinians mourn their relatives killed in an Israeli bombardment of UNRWA school at Nusseirat refugee camp, in front of the morgue of al-Aqsa Martyrs hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip, early Thursday, June 6, 2024. Military claims it was being used by Hamas", "body": "DEIR AL-BALAH: An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 30 people, including 23 women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nThe strike came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. It's the latest instance of troops sweeping back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven from their homes in what became the new state.\n\nMohammed al-Kareem, a displaced Palestinian sheltering near the hospital, described chaotic scenes outside the facility. He said vehicles arrived one after the other, as distressed people rushed wounded people into the emergency department. Videos circulating online appeared to show several wounded people being treated on the floor of the hospital, a common scene in Gaza's overwhelmed medical wards.\n\nFootage showed bodies wrapped in blankets or plastic bags being laid out in lines in the courtyard of the hospital, which was largely dark as staff try to conserve limited fuel for electricity. Al-Kareem said he saw people searching for their loved ones among bodies, and that one woman kept asking medical workers to open the wraps on the bodies to see if her son was inside.\n\n\"The situation is tragic,\" he said.\n\nThe Israeli military said Hamas had embedded a \"compound\" within the school and that Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants inside were using it as a shelter where they were planning attacks against Israeli troops, though it did not immediately offer evidence. {"uri": "8164425956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:04:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:04:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:03:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.kob.com/news/us-and-world-news/the-latest-over-30-dead-in-israeli-strikes-overnight-in-gaza-including-on-a-school-turned-shelter/", "title": "The Latest | Over 30 dead in Israeli strikes overnight in Gaza, including on a school-turned-shelter", "body": "Dozens are dead after an Israeli strike hit a school-turned-shelter in Gaza overnight. Israel claimed Thursday the school was being used as a Hamas compound, without providing evidence.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home.\n\nInternational pressure has been mounting to limit civilian bloodshed in the Israel-Hamas war. Spain's foreign minister announced Thursday that the country would ask a United Nations court for permission to join South Africa's case accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza. United States President Joe Biden's administration has launched an intense drive to persuade Hamas and Israel to accept a new cease-fire and hostage release proposal, which has raised hopes of ending the war.\n\nIsrael's war against Hamas in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe eight-month war in Gaza has largely cut off the flow of food, medicine and other supplies to Palestinians who are facing widespread hunger. United Nations agencies say over 1 million in Gaza could experience the highest level of starvation by mid-July.\n\nIsrael launched the war after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack, in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Around 80 hostages captured on Oct. 7 are believed to still be alive in Gaza, alongside the remains of 43 others.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Israeli strike on a Gaza school that military says was being used by Hamas kills 30 people.\n\n-- Spain applies to join South Africa's case at top the U.N. court accusing Israel of genocide.\n\n-- One image, millions of eyeballs: A social media effort to draw attention to Rafah surges.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nSPAIN APPLIES TO JOIN SOUTH AFRICA'S CASE ACCUSING ISRAEL OF GENOCIDE\n\nMADRID -- Spain will ask a United Nations court for permission to join South Africa's case accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza, its foreign minister announced Thursday.\n\nSpain is the first European country to take the step after South Africa filed its case with the International Court of Justice in late 2023. It alleged that Israel was breaching the genocide convention in its military assault that has laid waste to large swaths of Gaza.\n\nMexico, Colombia, Nicaragua, Libya and the Palestinians have already requested to join the case currently being heard at the court in The Hague, Netherlands.\n\nThe court has ordered Israel to immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah but stopped short of ordering a cease-fire for the enclave. Israel has not complied.\n\nSpain's request to join the case is the latest move by the government of Socialist Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez to support peacemaking efforts in Gaza.\n\nIsrael denies it is committing genocide in its military operation to crush Hamas triggered by its deadly Oct. 7 attacks in southern Israel.\n\nHamas killed 1,200 people and took 250 more hostage in the surprise attacks. Israel's air and land attacks have killed 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nISRAELI STRIKE KILLS DOZENS AT A SCHOOL-TURNED-SHELTER IN GAZA\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military claimed was being used as a Hamas compound killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza in an apparent widening of its nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack. An international medical charity had reported soaring casualties even before Thursday's strike.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run TV had earlier reported a higher toll.\n\nThe Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations and that risk reduction steps were taken before the strike.\n\nThe war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack inside Israel that killed at least 1,200 people with 250 others taken hostage. The Israeli military campaign in the Gaza Strip has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, with hundreds of others killed in operations in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nYEMEN'S HOUTHI REBELS UNVEIL A NEW SOLID-FUEL MISSILE\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Yemen's Houthi rebels have unveiled a new, solid-fuel missile in their arsenal that resembles aspects of one earlier displayed by Iran that Tehran described as flying at hypersonic speeds.\n\nThe rebels fired their new \"Palestine\" missile, complete with a warhead painted like a Palestinian keffiyeh checkered scarf, at the southern Gulf of Aqaba port of Eilat in Israel on Monday. The attack set off air raid sirens but caused no reported damage or injuries.\n\nFootage released by the Houthis late Wednesday showed the Palestine being raised on what appeared to be a mobile launcher and rising quickly into the air with plumes of white smoke coming from its engine. White smoke is common with solid-fuel missiles.\n\nSolid-fuel missiles can be set up and fired faster than those containing liquid fuel. That's a key concern for the Houthis as their missile launch sites have been repeatedly targeted by U.S. and allied forces in recent months over the rebels' attacks on shipping through the Red Sea corridor. One such strike hit the Houthis even before they were able to launch their missile.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-380679293", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:04:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:04:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:27:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.wtaj.com/news/national-news/ap-the-latest-over-30-dead-in-israeli-strikes-overnight-in-gaza-including-on-a-school-turned-shelter/", "title": "The Latest | Over 30 dead in Israeli strikes overnight in Gaza, including on a school-turned-shelter", "body": "Dozens are dead after an Israeli strike hit a school-turned-shelter in Gaza overnight. Israel claimed Thursday the school was being used as a Hamas compound, without providing evidence.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home.\n\nInternational pressure has been mounting to limit civilian bloodshed in the Israel-Hamas war. Spain's foreign minister announced Thursday that the country would ask a United Nations court for permission to join South Africa's case accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza. United States President Joe Biden's administration has launched an intense drive to persuade Hamas and Israel to accept a new cease-fire and hostage release proposal, which has raised hopes of ending the war.\n\nIsrael's war against Hamas in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe eight-month war in Gaza has largely cut off the flow of food, medicine and other supplies to Palestinians who are facing widespread hunger. United Nations agencies say over 1 million in Gaza could experience the highest level of starvation by mid-July.\n\nIsrael launched the war after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack, in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Around 80 hostages captured on Oct. 7 are believed to still be alive in Gaza, alongside the remains of 43 others.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Israeli strike on a Gaza school that military says was being used by Hamas kills 30 people.\n\n-- Spain applies to join South Africa's case at top the U.N. court accusing Israel of genocide.\n\n-- One image, millions of eyeballs: A social media effort to draw attention to Rafah surges.\n\n-- Israeli settlers in the West Bank were hit with international sanctions. It only emboldened them.\n\n-- Yemen's Houthi rebels unveil solid-fuel 'Palestine' missile that resembles Iranian hypersonic.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nSPAIN APPLIES TO JOIN SOUTH AFRICA'S CASE ACCUSING ISRAEL OF GENOCIDE\n\nMADRID -- Spain will ask a United Nations court for permission to join South Africa's case accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza, its foreign minister announced Thursday.\n\nSpain is the first European country to take the step after South Africa filed its case with the International Court of Justice in late 2023. It alleged that Israel was breaching the genocide convention in its military assault that has laid waste to large swaths of Gaza.\n\nMexico, Colombia, Nicaragua, Libya and the Palestinians have already requested to join the case currently being heard at the court in The Hague, Netherlands.\n\nThe court has ordered Israel to immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah but stopped short of ordering a cease-fire for the enclave. Israel has not complied.\n\nSpain's request to join the case is the latest move by the government of Socialist Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez to support peacemaking efforts in Gaza.\n\nIsrael denies it is committing genocide in its military operation to crush Hamas triggered by its deadly Oct. 7 attacks in southern Israel.\n\nHamas killed 1,200 people and took 250 more hostage in the surprise attacks. Israel's air and land attacks have killed 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nISRAELI STRIKE KILLS DOZENS AT A SCHOOL-TURNED-SHELTER IN GAZA\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school-turned-shelter in central Gaza that the military claimed was being used as a Hamas compound killed at least 30 people, including five children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe strike came after the military said it was launching new air and ground operations in central Gaza in an apparent widening of its nearly eight-month offensive, launched after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack. An international medical charity had reported soaring casualties even before Thursday's strike.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah received at least 30 bodies from the strike on the school run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees -- known by the acronym UNRWA -- and another six from a separate strike on a home, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Hamas-run TV had earlier reported a higher toll.\n\nThe Israeli military claimed, without immediately offering evidence, that Hamas and the Islamic Jihad used the school as cover for their operations and that risk reduction steps were taken before the strike.\n\nThe war began with Hamas' Oct. 7 attack inside Israel that killed at least 1,200 people with 250 others taken hostage. The Israeli military campaign in the Gaza Strip has killed at least 36,000 Palestinians, with hundreds of others killed in operations in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nYEMEN'S HOUTHI REBELS UNVEIL A NEW SOLID-FUEL MISSILE\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Yemen's Houthi rebels have unveiled a new, solid-fuel missile in their arsenal that resembles aspects of one earlier displayed by Iran that Tehran described as flying at hypersonic speeds.\n\nThe rebels fired their new \"Palestine\" missile, complete with a warhead painted like a Palestinian keffiyeh checkered scarf, at the southern Gulf of Aqaba port of Eilat in Israel on Monday. The attack set off air raid sirens but caused no reported damage or injuries.\n\nFootage released by the Houthis late Wednesday showed the Palestine being raised on what appeared to be a mobile launcher and rising quickly into the air with plumes of white smoke coming from its engine. White smoke is common with solid-fuel missiles.\n\nSolid-fuel missiles can be set up and fired faster than those containing liquid fuel. That's a key concern for the Houthis as their missile launch sites have been repeatedly targeted by U.S. and allied forces in recent months over the rebels' attacks on shipping through the Red Sea corridor. One such strike hit the Houthis even before they were able to launch their missile.", "source": {"uri": "wtaj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTAJ - www.wtaj.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164183557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:32:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:32:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:31:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/1907899/israeli-strike-gaza-school-palestine", "title": "Israeli airstrike on UN-run school kills dozens of Palestinians", "body": "An Israeli strike early Thursday on a school sheltering displaced Palestinians in central Gaza killed more than 45 people, including women and children, according to local health officials. The Israeli military said Hamas militants were operating from within the school.\n\nThe strike came after the military announced a new ground and air assault in several refugee camps in central Gaza, pursuing Hamas militants it says have regrouped there. It's the latest instance of troops sweeping back into sections of the Gaza Strip they have previously invaded, underscoring the resilience of the militant group despite Israel's nearly eight-month onslaught in the territory.\n\nWitnesses and hospital officials said the predawn strike hit the al-Sardi School, run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees known by the acronym UNRWA. The school was filled with Palestinians who had fled Israeli offensives and bombardment in northern Gaza, they said.\n\nAyman Rashed, a man displaced from Gaza City who was sheltering at the school, said the missiles hit classrooms on the second and third floor where families were sheltering. He said he helped carry out five dead, including an old man and two children, one with his head shattered open. \"It was dark, with no electricity, and we struggled to get out the victims,\" Rashed said.\n\nThe Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in the nearby town of Deir al-Balah received at least 33 dead from the strike, including 14 children and nine women, according to hospital records and an Associated Press reporter at the hospital. Another strike on a house overnight killed six people, according to the records. Both strikes occurred in Nuseirat, one of several built-up refugee camps in Gaza dating to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation, when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled or were driven
